column1: Sertolovo (Russian: Се́ртолово; Finnish: Sierattala) is a town in Vsevolozhsky District of Leningrad Oblast
column3: located north of St. Petersburg. Population: 47

column1: It was founded in 1936 on the place of a former settlement of Ingrian Finns
column2: whose inhabitants were deported. The settlement was mentioned in earlier sources as Sirotala. In 1936
column3: military personnel moved in and in 1939—1940
column4: Sertolovo was used as a base from where troops were sent to the Winter War. From the beginning
column5: Sertolovo was a part of Vsevolozhsky District of Leningrad Oblast. During World War II
column6: it was not occupied and was together with the city of Leningrad surrounded by German and Finnish troops. After the war
column7: there was almost no civil population in Sertolovo
column8: until massive housing construction started in the 1950s. In 1977
column9: Sertolovo was granted urban-type settlement status
column11: town status. It was the town of oblast significance until 2010
column12: when the administrative structure of Leningrad Oblast was harmonized with its municipal structure. At that time
column13: Sertolovo became a town of district significance.

column1: Within the framework of administrative divisions
column3: together with the settlement of Zapadnaya Litsa
column4: incorporated within Vsevolozhsky District as Sertolovskoye Settlement Municipal Formation. As a municipal division
column5: Sertolovskoye Settlement Municipal Formation is incorporated within Vsevolozhsky Municipal District as Sertolovskoye Urban Settlement.

column1: The economy of Sertolovo is based on military installations. About 70% of the population as of 2009 were the military personnel and their families.
Industrial enterprises in Sertolovo produce concrete constructions and plastic containers.
Sertolovo is essentially a suburb of St. Petersburg and is included into the suburban road network. In particular
column2: it is located on the highway heading in the direction of Vyborg.

column1: The town is several kilometers northeast of the Pesochnaya railway platform located on the railroad which connects St. Petersburg and Vyborg.
